elements.title: William George Carlile Kent (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that William George Carlile Kent (pictured) was court-martialled for disobeying deposed Governor William Bligh's order to destroy Sydney?

elements.title: Acoustic Atlas (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Acoustic Atlas at Montana State University Library helped to create a public domain archive of sounds from Yellowstone National Park?

elements.title: Daniel Arnoldi (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in 1836, a jury ignored the judge's advice and found Daniel Arnoldi guilty of assaulting a black man?

elements.title: Crippled (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in Crippled, author Frances Ryan describes a disabled British woman who was unable to afford heating or her specialist meals due to an austerity programme that began in 2010?

elements.title: A. O. Granger (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that amateur astronomer A. O. Granger expanded his home to include the largest observatory and telescope in the southeastern United States?

elements.title: Songbird Sings the Classics (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in the concert Songbird Sings the Classics, Regine Velasquez paid homage to the music of Burt Bacharach, Leonard Bernstein, Michel Legrand, Henry Mancini, and Barry Manilow?

elements.title: George Verdak (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Ballet Russe de Monte-Carlo dancer George Verdak was awarded an honorary doctorate by Butler University?

elements.title: Scilly Boys (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Scilly Boys' idea to try and beat the transatlantic rowing record was started while they were at the pub?
